The development of integrated photocatalysts to enhance the charge carrier separation efficiency of bimetallic oxides is a crucial strategy for achieving photocatalytic hydrogen production. In this study, the crystalline structure and synthesis results of NiCo₂O₄ and graphdiyne-Cu₃P (G-CP) catalysts were systematically investigated using X-ray diffraction and Raman spectroscopy. The Raman spectroscopic results confirmed the presence of graphite-like carbon nitride in G-CP, further validating the successful synthesis of the catalyst. Photoelectrochemical performance tests demonstrated that the heterojunction formed between G-CP and NiCo₂O₄ effectively reduced the recombination rates of charge carriers, with NCOGCP-80 exhibiting the highest photocurrent response intensity and the lowest resistance, indicating exceptional hydrogen evolution performance. In photocatalytic hydrogen evolution experiments, NCOGCP-80 achieved a hydrogen evolution amount of 312.22 µmol (6244.4 µmol·g⁻¹·h⁻¹), representing increases of 9.83 and 4.66 times compared to the individual catalysts. Finally, the formation of the S-scheme heterojunction between G-CP and NiCo₂O₄ is verified through theoretical calculations and in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Graphical abstract The results of this study also demonstrate that the Z-scheme heterojunction between G-CP and NiCo₂O₄ not only preserves their respective band structures but also effectively reduces the recombination rate of photogenerated charge carriers, thereby significantly enhancing the efficiency of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. Image, graphical abstract Keywords NiCo₂O4 Graphdiyne-Cu₃P Hydrogen evolution S-scheme heterojunction Photocatalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Photocatalytic hydrogen production is a renewable energy technology that utilizes light energy to drive the water splitting process for hydrogen generation, holding significant potential for reducing dependence on traditional fossil fuels [1–3]. As the global demand for sustainable energy continues to rise, photocatalytic hydrogen production has garnered considerable attention due to its environmental friendliness and high energy conversion efficiency [4,5]. This technology relies on the development of efficient catalysts to enhance reaction rates and hydrogen yield [6,7]. Therefore, exploring novel catalytic materials, such as metal oxides, carbon-based materials, and their composite catalysts, has become an important research direction in this field [8–10]. To achieve optimal catalytic performance, methods such as doping, structural modulation, modification, and the construction of heterostructures are commonly employed to alter the light absorption range, improve the separation efficiency of photo-generated electron-hole pairs, and enhance the redox capabilities of electrons and holes [11–13]. In recent years, the application of bimetallic materials in photocatalysis has gradually expanded. With ongoing research, NiCo₂O₄ has attracted attention due to its abundant resource availability, low cost, and excellent electronic conductivity [14]. In the structure of NiCo₂O₄, nickel atoms are located in octahedral positions, while cobalt atoms are randomly distributed in both tetrahedral and octahedral positions [15,16]. This unique structure enables interactions between the redox pairs Ni₃⁺/Ni₂⁺ and Co₃⁺/Co₂⁺, resulting in enhanced conductivity compared to single-metal materials. Its three-dimensional structure not only improves electrical conductivity but also provides more active sites, facilitating catalytic reactions. Furthermore, graphdiyne, as a novel carbon material, has increasingly gained attention in the study of photocatalytic hydrogen production, demonstrating its potential value in sustainable energy applications [17–19]. Graphdiyne exhibits high electrical conductivity and a large specific surface area, significantly enhancing photocatalytic activity and effectively accelerating reaction rates [20–22]. Its theoretical bandgap characteristics help reduce the recombination rate of photo-generated electrons and holes [23–25]. When graphdiyne is combined with Cu₃P to form an integrated catalyst, it is expected to further enhance the photocatalytic performance of Cu₃P [26,27]. Therefore, the combination of graphdiyne-Cu₃P and bimetallic materials like NiCo₂O₄ holds promise for achieving more efficient photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reactions. In this study, we synthesized a graphdiyne-Cu₃P (G-CP) composite catalyst and subsequently constructed an S-scheme heterojunction by integrating NiCo₂O₄ with G-CP via a simple physical mixing method. The crystal structures and successful synthesis of NiCo₂O₄ and G-CP were confirmed through X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectroscopy, with the latter explicitly verifying the formation of the G-CP framework. Photoelectrochemical characterization revealed that the G-CP/NiCo₂O₄ heterojunction significantly suppressed charge recombination, leading to enhanced charge separation efficiency. Notably, the NCOGCP-80 composite exhibited the highest photocurrent response and achieved an exceptional hydrogen evolution rate, representing a substantial improvement over the individual catalysts. This superior performance can be attributed to the formation of an S-scheme heterojunction, which not only facilitates efficient spatial charge separation but also preserves the strong redox capabilities of the photogenerated carriers, thereby boosting photocatalytic activity. The morphology and structural properties of the synthesized materials were systematically investigated using advanced characterization techniques. Furthermore, based on photoelectrochemical measurements and hydrogen evolution results, we conducted a mechanistic analysis and complemented it with density functional theory (DFT) calculations to elucidate the underlying electronic interactions. These findings allowed us to propose a plausible mechanism for the enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen evolution observed in the composite system. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of graphdiyne-Cu3P (G-CP) Initially, 4.3 mL of trimethylsilyl and 35 mL of tetrahydrofuran were introduced into a three-neck flask. At −78 °C, 12 mL of n-butyllithium was gradually added to the mixture, and the reaction was allowed to proceed for 30 min. Following this, a solution of 4.20 g (30 mmol) of anhydrous zinc chloride in 20 mL of tetrahydrofuran was slowly incorporated, and the temperature was increased to 23 °C for an additional 30 min. Then, 25 mL of toluene, 1.10 g of hexabromobenzene, and 0.50 g of Pd(PPh₃)₄ were added, and the reaction was maintained at 80 °C for 3 days. After the reaction completion, 20 mL of 1 mol/L dilute hydrochloric acid was introduced to the mixture, followed by extraction with ethyl acetate. The organic layer was collected, washed several times, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, and subsequently subjected to column chromatography using a hexane/dichloromethane (1:4) eluent to isolate the intermediate. This intermediate was then dissolved in 20 mL of tetrahydrofuran, to which 0.4 mL of tetrabutylammonium fluoride was added. The mixture was reacted at 8 °C for 10 min. After this step, it was washed with ethyl acetate, then with saturated brine, and finally dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate before being concentrated to isolate the intermediate. Lastly, the intermediate was mixed with 1.50 g of nano-Cu in 75 mL of pyridine and reacted at 60 °C for 2 days to obtain the precursor. The precursor was then subjected to phosphidation with NaH₂PO₂·H₂O at a ratio of 1:10 and was calcined at 300 °C for 2 h to ultimately obtain the G-CP product. 2.2 Preparation of NiCo2O4 First, 0.8 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone, 1.45 g of hexahydrate cobalt nitrate (Co(NO₃)₂·6H₂O), and 0.73 g of hexahydrate nickel nitrate (Ni(NO₃)₂·6H₂O) were weighed and dissolved in 60 mL of deionized water. The mixture was stirred for 1 h until fully dissolved. Next, 1.20 g of urea was added to the solution, and after complete dissolution, the mixed solution was transferred to a 100 mL polytetrafluoroethylene autoclave. The autoclave was then placed in an oven at 180 °C for a reaction time of 8 h. After the reaction, the reaction solution was subjected to centrifugation to remove the solvent and the unreacted materials, resulting in the formation of a precipitate. The precipitate was then dried at 60 °C. Finally, the dried product was placed in a tubular furnace and calcined at 500 °C for 2 h, with a heating rate of 5 °C/min during the calcination process, ultimately synthesizing NiCo₂O₄ materials with a sea urchin-like structure. 2.3 Preparation of NiCo2O4/graphdiyne-Cu3P The preparation of NiCo2O4/graphdiyne-Cu3P-X (NCOGCP-X) was carried out using a simple mechanochemical grinding method, where X denotes the mass ratio of G-CP to NiCo₂O₄. Specifically, 0.10 g of NiCo₂O₄, 0.08 g of G-CP, and 5 mL of ethanol were mixed and subjected to sonication, followed by grinding until dry. This process was performed five times to obtain the sample NCOGCP-80. 2.4 Characterization The crystallinity of the catalyst samples was determined using an X-ray diffractometer system (Rigaku Rint-2000) equipped with copper Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Validation of the successful preparation of G-Cu3P was conducted using Raman spectroscopy (LabRam HR Evolution) and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy. The morphological features of the samples were analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-6701F JEOL) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100). Surface elemental valence states were determined using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi) and a Shimadzu spectrophotometer (UV-2550, with BaSO4 as a reference background) for UV–vis diffuse reflectance measurements. Photoluminescence (PL) and time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) of the samples were tested using a steady-state spectrometer (FluorOMax-4, HORIBA) and a single-photon counting controller (Floor Hub, Floor Center). The electrochemical experiments were carried out on an electrochemical workstation (VersaSTAT4–400, AMETEK) with Using a three-electrode system comprising a saturated calomel electrode, a platinum electrode, and a working electrode made of ITO conductive glass. 2.5 Hydrogen evolution experiments For instance, varying amounts of Eosin Y (EY) (X = 0, 10, 20, 30, 40 mg) and 10 mg of catalyst were dispersed in 30 mL of triethanolamine liquor (pH= 10, 15 vol % TEOA) solution and ensure uniform dispersion. Subsequently, the air was evacuated from the system using nitrogen, after which the hydrogen production experiment was initiated. Hydrogen generation was quantified using gas chromatography, the carrier gas is nitrogen. The gas chromatograph system model used was the Teccomp GC7900 with nitrogen as the carrier gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Constituent information The crystal structure and preparation results of the catalyst were analyzed using XRD and Raman spectroscopy [28]. Fig. 1(a) presents the XRD results for NiCo₂O₄, which are consistent with the XRD standard card (PDF # 2-1074). Fig. 1(b) displays the crystal structure of GDY-Cu₃P (referred to as G-CP). By simulating the XRD spectrum of G-CP and comparing it with the standard Cu₃P XRD pattern (PDF #2-1263), it can be observed that the main component in G-CP is Cu₃P. This result suggests that the material is not merely G-CP. Raman spectroscopy was conducted to confirm the presence of GDY in G-CP (Fig. 1(c)). In the Raman spectrum of G-CP, in addition to the distinct G and D bands, there are noticeable vibrations in the 1800 to 2200 cm⁻¹ range [29–31]. The vibrations in this region typically arise from the stretching vibrations of –CC– and –CC–CC– indicating the presence of GDY within G-CP [32,33]. These results clearly demonstrate the successful synthesis of G-CP. Fig. 1(d) shows the XRD spectrum of NCOGCP-80, where the (3 0 0) and (1 1 3) crystal planes of G-CP can be observed. This indicates that NCOGCP-80 is composed of NiCo₂O₄ and G-CP. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was employed to examine the elemental composition of the catalyst. In Fig. 2(a) , the C 1s spectrum is split into four peaks located at 284 eV (sp²), 285 eV (sp), and 286 eV (sp). After compositing with Ni₄Mo₄O₁₉, the binding energy of C 1s primarily shifts towards a increase direction. Fig. 2(b) shows that the Cu 2p peaks at 932 eV and 935 eV correspond to Cu⁺ and Cu²⁺, respectively, and the binding energy of Cu 2p also shifts downwards [34–36]. In Fig. 2(c), the P 2p signal at 134 eV suggests the existence of P–O bonds within the composite material [37–39]. In Fig. 2(d), the binding energy peak at 855 eV corresponds to the Ni 2p₃/₂ orbital, while the peak at 861 eV is its satellite peak [40,41]. From Fig. 2(e), the Co 2p XPS spectrum reveals six fitted peaks, where peaks at 780 eV and 795 eV are attributed to Co³⁺, and those at 781 eV and 796 eV correspond to Co²⁺, with the remaining peaks being satellite peaks [42–44]. The O 1s XPS spectrum displays three peaks (Fig. 2(f)), located at 530 eV (CoO), 531 eV (surface OH), and 533 eV (adsorbed O₂) [45,46]. These results indicate that NCOGCP-80 is a combination of these two distinct materials. By comparing the binding energies between the individual materials and the composite catalyst, it is observed that Ni 2p, Co 2p and O 1s exhibit increased binding energies, while Cu 2p and P 2p show decreased binding energies. This suggests that the charge density at the surface of NiCo₂O₄ is reduced, while the surface charge density of G-CP is increased. The modification in surface charge density can be attributed to both charge transfer across the interface and molecular rearrangement occurring at the NiCo₂O₄/G-CP contact interface. These phenomena lead to the formation of a localized built-in electric field at the heterojunction, serving as an effective driving force for the separation and migration of photogenerated charge carriers, thereby significantly boosting the photocatalytic reaction kinetics. The surface morphology and lattice fringes of the photocatalyst were observed using SEM and TEM [47]. In Fig. 3 (a–c), it can be seen that G-CP is composed of nanosheets assembled into nanoparticles, while NiCo₂O₄ exhibits a sea urchin-like structure. In NCOGCP-80, the G-CP particles are clearly loaded onto the surface of NiCo₂O₄. The surface elemental analysis of NCOGCP-80 (Fig. 3(d)) shows that the elemental composition of NCOGCP-100 includes C, Cu, P, Ni, Co, and O. Further characterization of the surface elemental structure and apparent morphology of the composite catalyst was performed. Fig. 3(e) presents the TEM image of NCOGCP-100, where the structural dimensions of NiCo₂O₄ are much larger than those of G-CP, indicating a clear distinction between the two. In the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image (Fig. 3(f)), two different lattice fringes can be observed, corresponding to the (1 1 2) crystal plane of Cu₃P in G-CP (d = 0.25 nm) and the (1 1 1) crystal plane of NiCo₂O₄ (d = 0.46 nm). 3.2 Electrochemistry and optical information By testing the photocatalytic performance of the catalysts, we can analyze the charge separation efficiency and light absorption capacity [48]. In Fig. 4(a) , the fluorescence intensity results are presented as EY > G-CP > NiCo₂O₄ > NCOGCP-80, indicating that the heterojunction formed by G-CP and NiCo₂O₄ effectively improves the recombination rate of photogenerated charge carriers. According to the results of the time-resolved photoluminescence experiments (see Fig. 4(b)), the lifetimes of EY, G-CP, NiCo₂O₄, and NCOGCP-80 are 0.427 ns, 0.028 ns, 0.006 ns, and 0.006 ns, respectively. This indicates that NiCo₂O₄ plays a dominant role in the electron transfer rate of NCOGCP-80. Fig. 4(c) demonstrates the UV-visible light absorption abilities of NiCo₂O₄, G-CP, and NCOGCP-80. The absorption of NCOGCP-80 significantly increases with longer visible wavelengths, indicating that it can absorb more light at these longer wavelengths. Based on the formula (αhv)1/n=A(hv–Eg), Fig. 4(d) reveals that the band gaps for NiCo₂O₄ and G-CP are 1.06 eV and 1.42 eV, respectively. The Mott-Schottky curves shown in Fig. 4(e, f) indicate that the flat band potentials (Efb) are −0.44 V and 0.94 V for NiCo₂O₄, −0.12 V and 1.53 V for G-CP, and −0.23 V and 1.44 V for NCOGCP-80. The experimental results show that the reduction potential of NCOGCP-80 is closer to that of NiCo₂O₄, while the oxidation potential is closer to that of G-CP. Using the empirical formulas ESCE=Efb−0.2 and ENHE=ESCE+0.24, we find that the ECB of NiCo₂O₄ is −0.40 eV and that of G-CP is −0.08 eV. From Eg=EVB+ECB, we derive the EVB values, with NiCo₂O₄ at 0.66 eV and G-CP at 1.34 eV. As shown in Fig. 4(g), NCOGCP-80 exhibits the strongest photocurrent response intensity, indicating that the synergistic effect between NiCo₂O₄ and G-CP significantly enhances the density of photogenerated charge carriers on the catalyst surface, which is beneficial for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. The Nyquist plots can quantitatively depict the charge transfer resistance of the catalysts (Figure (h)), revealing that NCOGCP-80 has the lowest arc curvature radius. This result suggests that the interaction between NiCo₂O₄ and G-CP can accelerate the migration rate of charge carriers. Additionally, NCOGCP-80 shows the highest current density and the lowest overpotential, indicating that the energy barrier for hydrogen evolution is significantly lower than that of the individual catalysts (Fig. 4(i)). By testing the photocatalytic performance of the catalysts, we obtain the band structure of NiCo₂O₄ and G-CP, while also providing insight into the mechanism between NiCo₂O₄ and G-CP. 3.3 Photocatalytic performance The photocatalytic hydrogen evolution experiment was conducted to assess the hydrogen evolution performance of the catalysts [49]. Fig. 5(a) displays the hydrogen evolution amounts of G-CP, NiCo₂O₄, and NCOGCP over a five-hour period. Among them, NCOGCP-80 achieved a hydrogen evolution amount of 123.68 µmol (2473 µmol·g⁻¹·h⁻¹), which is 9.83 and 4.66 times that of G-CP and NiCo₂O₄, respectively. This result indicates that the composite of G-CP and NiCo₂O₄ can effectively enhance the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution performance of the catalyst. By adjusting the mass ratio of G-CP to NiCo₂O₄, NCOGCP-X samples were obtained (Fig. 5(b)). It was found that when the ratio of G-CP to NiCo₂O₄ is 60, the composite catalyst achieves the maximum hydrogen evolution amount over the five hours. In the absence of any catalyst, no hydrogen evolution reaction occurs. However, the content of the photosensitizer remains crucial for the performance of the catalyst. Fig. 5(c) presents the hydrogen evolution amounts of NCOGCP-80 under different EY content conditions over a five-hour period. The results indicate that NCOGCP-80 reaches its optimal performance with an EY content of 30 mg (6244.4 µmol·g⁻¹·h⁻¹). A small amount of EY may lead to insufficient light absorption, which cannot effectively excite the required electron transfer process for the catalytic reaction. Conversely, an excessive amount of EY may result in the excessive transfer of excited-state electrons to the catalyst surface, accelerating the electron-hole recombination rate and reducing hydrogen production efficiency. Meanwhile, Table 1 demonstrates the comparison of hydrogen precipitation rates of similar catalysts, and it can be found that NCOGCP-80 has certain advantages in hydrogen evolution performance. Fig. 5(d) shows the cyclic stability experiment of NCOGCP-80, which exhibits stable hydrogen evolution capability during the first 10 h. After being left for 12 h, a subsequent hydrogen evolution experiment indicates that NCOGCP-80 still retains stable hydrogen evolution capacity. The structural stability of NCOGCP-80 can be further validated through XRD, SEM, and EDX conducted after the hydrogen evolution reaction. As shown in Fig. 5(e, f), there are no significant structural or morphological changes in NCOGCP-80 before and after the reaction, indicating that NCOGCP-80 exhibits good stability within the photosensitized system. 3.4 Density functional theory calculations The heterojunction structure of NiCo2O4 and G-CP was constructed to yield the NCOGCP model. Fig. 6(a) shows the top and side views of the NCOGCP, which are divided into two regions. Fig. 6(b) displays the charge difference density map of NCOGCP. The charge distribution values indicate that on the contact side, charges from NiCo2O4 are transferred to the GDY component, with the GDY layer further transmitting the charges transferred from NiCo2O4. Additionally, charge transfer to the Cu3P component occurs in the contact layer between GDY and Cu3P. This leads to the inference of the theoretical charge transfer process in NCOGCP: the charge transfer upon contact between NiCo2O4 and G-CP forms a strong built-in electric field; simultaneously, the uncontacted end of NiCo2O4 exhibits charge accumulation, while the uncontacted end of Cu3P shows charge depletion. Therefore, it can be concluded that the theoretical hydrogen evolution position in NCOGCP occurs at the uncontacted side of NiCo2O4. By establishing the k-path in the Brillouin zone at points A and B, Fig. 6(c,d) were obtained. In region A, it is evidently observed that there is no energy level crossing at 0 eV, while region B displays a distinct energy level crossover. This result further indicates that the effective number of migrating electrons generated by NiCo2O4 in the NCOGCP composition is greater than that of G-CP. 3.5 Possible photocatalytic mechanisms Through in situ XPS, we obtained compelling evidence for charge transfer in the composite catalyst under light irradiation. Fig. 7 (a–f) presents the detailed peak fitting of the XPS spectra. To facilitate the analysis of surface charge variations, we performed C correction normalization on the carbon main peak under both dark and light conditions. The results indicate that the binding energy of Cu 2p in the surface charge of G-CP increases, while the binding energy of P 2p decreases. Simultaneously, the binding energy of the main peak for NiCo2O4 also shows a decline. This suggests that the composite catalyst can effectively absorb visible light, leading to an increase in charge density and a corresponding decrease in binding energy. Under light irradiation, G-CP exhibits electron transfer to NiCo2O4, which further results in a decrease in the surface charge density of Cu 2p Additionally, only two peaks are observed in the O 1s spectrum, which is primarily due to the disappearance of adsorbed oxygen as a result of the degassing treatment. Based on the band structure information of G-CP and NiCo₂O₄, we have illustrated the band structure diagram prior to contact (Fig. 8(a) ). Charge rearrangement and bending of the energy bands occur at the contact of G-CP and NiCo₂O₄, forming a built-in electric field (Fig. 8(b)). According to the changes in situ XPS of the composite materials, we propose that the enhancement in hydrogen evolution performance between G-CP and NiCo₂O₄ is due to the formation of a S-scheme heterojunction (Fig. 8(c)). Under the light, the G-CP excited electrons excited from VB excitation jumped to CB, accelerated the transfer to the VB of NiCo2O4 under the action of the built-in electric field, and bonded with the holes on the VB of NiCo2O4, which lowered the rate of the photogenerated electron-hole complexation of NiCo2O4 and increased the rate of the hydrogen precipitation reaction. Furthermore, this structure preserves the original redox potentials while effectively reducing the recombination of photogenerated charge carriers, thereby improving photocatalytic performance. Specifically, under solar irradiation, EY molecules act as photosensitizers, achieving a triplet excited state through solar light absorption and reducing triethanolamine to the triplet excited state, thus providing additional active electrons for the catalytic system. Simultaneously, G-CP and NiCo₂O₄ absorb solar light, resulting in electron transitions in the valence band. NiCo₂O₄ has a shorter average electron lifetime and a lower energy barrier, indicating that it is more suitable for transferring photogenerated charge carriers to the surface. Driven by the built-in electric field, the electrons in G-CP flow toward the valence band of NiCo₂O₄, reducing the recombination rate of photogenerated charge carriers in NiCo₂O₄. Consequently, an electron accumulation occurs in the conduction band of NiCo₂O₄, which participates in the hydrogen evolution reaction, while hole accumulation in the valence band of G-CP facilitates the oxidation of the sacrificial reagent. 4 Conclusions This study successfully synthesized the composite catalyst NCOGCP-80 from NiCo₂O₄ and G-CP and systematically evaluated its photocatalytic hydrogen evolution performance. The XRD and Raman analysis confirmed the crystal structure and composition of the catalyst. The electrochemical testing results revealed that NCOGCP-80 has the optimal charge separation efficiency and light absorption capability, indicating its superior performance in photocatalysis. The results of this study also demonstrate that the S-scheme heterojunction between G-CP and NiCo₂O₄ not only preserves their respective band structures but also effectively reduces the recombination rate of photogenerated charge carriers, thereby significantly enhancing the efficiency of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. NCOGCP-80 exhibits promising potential in the field of photocatalysis, providing new insights for the design and development of future catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The development of integrated photocatalysts to enhance the charge carrier separation efficiency of bimetallic oxides is a crucial strategy for achieving photocatalytic hydrogen production. In this study, the crystalline structure and synthesis results of NiCo₂O₄ and graphdiyne-Cu₃P (G-CP) catalysts were systematically investigated using X-ray diffraction and Raman spectroscopy. The Raman spectroscopic results confirmed the presence of graphite-like carbon nitride in G-CP, further validating the successful synthesis of the catalyst. Photoelectrochemical performance tests demonstrated that the heterojunction formed between G-CP and NiCo₂O₄ effectively reduced the recombination rates of charge carriers, with NCOGCP-80 exhibiting the highest photocurrent response intensity and the lowest resistance, indicating exceptional hydrogen evolution performance. In photocatalytic hydrogen evolution experiments, NCOGCP-80 achieved a hydrogen evolution amount of 312.22 µmol (6244.4 µmol·g⁻¹·h⁻¹), representing increases of 9.83 and 4.66 times compared to the individual catalysts. Finally, the formation of the S-scheme heterojunction between G-CP and NiCo₂O₄ is verified through theoretical calculations and in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy.
